title: Samsung wants to boost BlackBerry alliance, not buy it | Trusted Reviews
description:
![BlackBerry
Passport](https://ksassets.timeincuk.net/wp/uploads/sites/54/2017/07/trusted-
reviews-placeholder-3.svg)

**Samsung has moved to deny reports it is[planning an acquisition of
BlackBerry](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/samsung-has-reportedly-
offered-5-billion-for-blackberry), saying it only wishes to boost its
partnership with the Canadian smartphone manufacturer.**

Reports last week had suggested a takeover worth around £5 billion could be
imminent, although both companies quickly shot down the speculation.

On Monday, the company’s co-chief executive and mobile chief J.K. Shin told
the [Wall Street Journal](http://www.wsj.com/articles/samsung-isnt-planning-
blackberry-acquisition-co-ceo-says-1421665607) he is only interested in
developing the existing partnership with the firm, rather than acquiring it.

“We want to work with BlackBerry and develop this partnership, not acquire the
company,” he said (via [Android
Central](http://www.androidcentral.com/samsung-may-extend-its-current-
partnership-blackberry-wont-buy-it)).

After the Reuters report (which the agency continues to stand behind) emerged
last week, many speculated Samsung may be chasing BlackBerry’s wealth of
patents in order to boost its own mobile line-up.

However, Shin told the WSJ, that Samsung already has 110,000 patents and was
not looking to grab BlackBerry’s 44,000.

**Read more:[Samsung Galaxy A7 vs Samsung Galaxy
S5](https://www.trustedreviews.com/opinions/samsung-galaxy-a7-vs-samsung-
galaxy-s5-how-does-the-new-mid-range-champ-fare)**  
  
Samsung and BlackBerry’s partnership dates back to November last year, when
two firms announced a deal to provide end-to-end security support for
enterprise users.

The Korean company said it would be [using BlackBerry’s security expertise to
boost its own KNOX platform](https://www.trustedreviews.com/news/blackberry-
to-lend-its-security-expertise-to-samsung-s-android-phones) in order to add
enhanced levels of security for users on the firm’s Galaxy-branded handsets
and tablets.

What the extension of that partnership may entail remains to be seen, but
today’s developments certainly seem to confirm BlackBerry won’t be ending up a
Samsung-owned company any time soon.
